awd_titl_txt: Renewal of DeafTEC: Technological Education Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students

por.por_cntn:
DeafTEC: Technological Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students is an NSF-funded Advanced Technological Education National Center of Excellence established in 2011 at the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, a college of the Rochester Institute of Technology. The goal of DeafTEC is to increase the number of deaf and hard-of-hearing (deaf/hh) individuals in highly skilled technician jobs where they are currently underrepresented and underutilized.

 DeafTEC aims to broaden the participation in technician careers among deaf/hh individuals by providing them, as well as their teachers, counselors, employers, and co-workers, with the resources that will help them succeed both in the classroom and on the job.

During this renewal grant, DeafTEC has focused on capacity building and the creation of an infrastructure through: 

  1. Regional partnerships to cooperatively promote best practices in educating and employing deaf/hh individuals.
  2. A comprehensive website that will ultimately serve as a clearinghouse for information related to technical education and technician careers for deaf/hh students, their parents, teachers and employers.
  3. An expansion of its national dual credit program, Project Fast Forward.
  4. The development of new curricula for national dissemination.
  5. The creation of resources for community college faculty on best practices for teaching military veterans with hearing loss.

Regional Partnership Model

The goal of the DeafTEC partnership model is to build a mutually supportive professional community in selected regions of the country to improve access to technological education and employment for deaf/hh students. This train-the-trainer model involves partnerships with a high school, a community college, and several industries in each of four regions: California, Florida, Illinois, and Texas. Personnel from each regional partner were trained to offer DeafTEC workshops on best teaching practices, instructional materials and strategies for helping deaf/hh students develop skills in English and math, and strategies for employers to successfully create inclusive workplaces for deaf/hh individuals. During this funding period, DeafTEC partners offered 130 workshops to a total of 2,131 educators and 62 STEM camps/activities to 2,581 deaf/hh high school and middle school students.

Dual Credit Program

Project Fast Forward is model for offering a national STEM dual credit program. It was funded as an NSF ATE project, award DUE #060276, prior to it being included as a DeafTEC initiative. In February 2020, Project Fast Forward transitioned to a fully institutionalized pre-college program in NTID’s Division of Academic Affairs.

Under this DeafTEC renewal period, Project Fast Forward has:

  • Increased the number partner schools from 28 to 41 high schools in 25 States
  • Offered professional development to 22 high school counselors
  • Offered professional development to 85 teachers
  • Increased STEM dual credit course offerings from 10 to 13
  • Offered 179 STEM dual credit course sections in high schools
  • Registered 1,089 students in STEM dual credit courses
  • Awarded 2,037 college credits to 679 students who passed STEM dual credit courses

 DeafTEC Website (www.deaftec.org)

 This comprehensive website serves as a national resource on technical education and technician careers for deaf/hh students, their parents, teachers and future employers. Materials on the website include:

 

  • STEM awareness and employment materials featuring videos of deaf STEM professionals and information on technician careers.
  • Employer resources to help employers hire, onboard and create inclusive environments for deaf/hh employees including an online course for employers, coworkers, HR business leaders, and other inclusion/diversity professionals on these topics.
  • Best practices for instruction that provides extensive resources on effective strategies for teaching deaf/hh students, strategies for writing in the STEM discipline, and strategies for teaching math which includes over 60 accessible math tutorial videos
  • STEM sign video dictionary includes signs for information technology, lab sciences and math 

Online Curriculum 

STEM Career Awareness curriculum. This four-unit, 30-lesson curriculum aims to increase the educators’ abilities to teach introductory STEM concepts specifically to deaf/hh middle and high school students. Accompanying the curriculum is a series of videos with deaf/hh high school students interviewing deaf/hh college students in STEM majors about college life, courses they are taking, careers, etc.

Job Search Strategies course. In this self-paced, nine-module course, students work on developing skills for their job search. Topics include setting career goals, researching companies, resume writing, interviewing skills, as well as understanding workplace expectations, communication strategies, workplace accommodations, and monitoring their social media presence.

Teaching Student Veterans with Hearing Loss.

The Project Good to Go (PG2G) website serves as anational resource for community college faculty by providing best practices for teaching student veterans with hearing loss in STEM classes. The website contains expanded information on DeafTEC’s Top Ten Things that Student Veterans Would Like Faculty to Know document. This document is the result of student veteran participation in focus groups/surveys and is the underpinning of our related professional development offering. The PG2G team has offered seven professional development events to over 264 community college faculty/staff related to the Top Ten document.

 


 


Last Modified: 10/30/2020
Modified by: Donna Lange
